node.title: 264: spaces are not allowed in section paths
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose expert or users,
I downloaded the input file from an attachment to an article. After formatting it, run it on MOOSE. This happens. What is the reason? I'm using Windows 10. The rest of the tutorial examples will work.
WARNING
setInputFile exception: /home/wjc/projects/horse/problems/ex01.i:264: spaces are not allowed in section paths
Thank you.

Hello
Can you please paste the input file here?
Guillaume

[Mesh]
  # input file.
  # Define mesh. 2-D system, simulation size 200*200.
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 2
  nx = 200
  xmax = 200
  ny = 200
  ymax = 200
[]

[Variables]
  # variables. w: chemical potential, eta: order parameter, pot: applied overpotential.  
  [./w]
  [../]
  [./eta]
  [../]
  [./pot]
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
  # Creating functions for initial conditions.
  [./ic_func_eta]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 0.5*(1.0-1.0*tanh((x-20)*2))
  [../]
  [./ic_func_c]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./ic_func_pot]
    type = ParsedFunction
    value = -0.225*(1.0-tanh((x-20)*2))
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  # Initial conditions.
  [./eta]
    variable = eta
    type = FunctionIC
    function = ic_func_eta
  [../]
  [./w]
    variable = w
    type = FunctionIC
    function = ic_func_c
  [../]
  [./pot]
    variable = pot
    type = FunctionIC
    function = ic_func_pot
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  # Boundary conditions.
  [./bottom_eta]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = 'eta'
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./top_eta]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = 'eta'
    boundary = 'top'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./left_eta]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = 'eta'
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 1
  [../]
  [./right_eta]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = 'eta'
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./bottom_w]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = 'w'
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./top_w]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = 'w'
    boundary = 'top'
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./left_w]
    type = NeumannBC
    variable = 'w'
    boundary = 'left'
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./right_w]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = 'w'
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 0.0
  [../]
  [./left_pot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = 'pot'
    boundary = 'left'
    value = -0.45
  [../]
  [./right_pot]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = 'pot'
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 0
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./w_dot]
    # First part of equation 3 in main text . chi*dw/dt
    type = SusceptibilityTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    f_name = chi
    args = 'w'
  [../]
  [./Diffusion1]
    # Intrinsic diffusion part of equation 3 in main text.
    type = MatDiffusion
    variable = w
    D_name = D
  [../]
  [./Diffusion2]
    # Migration.
    type = Migration
    variable = w
    cv = eta
    Q_name = 0.
    QM_name = DN
    cp = pot
  [../]
  [./coupled_etadot]
    # Coupling between w and eta.
    type = CoupledSusceptibilityTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = eta
    f_name = ft
    args = 'eta'
  [../]
  [./Cond]
    # Conduction, left handside of equation 4 in main text.
    type = Conduction
    variable = pot
    cp = eta
    cv = w
    Q_name = Le1
    QM_name = 0.
  [../]
  [./coupled_pos]
    # Source term for Equation 4 in main text.
    type = CoupledSusceptibilityTimeDerivative
    variable = pot
    v = eta
    f_name = ft2
    args = 'eta'
  [../]
  [./BV]
    # Bulter-volmer equation, right hand side of Equation 1 in main text.
    type = Kinetics
    variable = eta
    f_name = G
    cp=pot
    cv=eta
  [../]
  [./AC_bulk]
    # Driving force from switching barrier, right hand side of Equation 1 in main text.
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = eta
    f_name = FF
  [../]
  [./AC_int]
    # interfacial energy
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta
  [../]
  [./Noiseeta]
    type = LangevinNoise
    variable = eta
    amplitude = 0.04
  [../]
  [./e_dot]
    # deta/dt
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./constants]
    # kappa_op: gradient coefficient;  M0:diffucion coefficient of Li+ in electrolyte
    #  S1, S2 conductivity of electrode and electrolyte; L: kinetic coefficient; Ls: electrochemical kinetic coefficient; B: Barrier height;
    #  es, el: difference in the chemical potential of lithium and neutral components on the electrode/electrolyte phase at initial equilibrium state;
    # us, ul: free energy density of the electrode/electrolyte phases. Defined in Ref. 20 and 26 of the main text; A: prefactor; AA: nF/(R*T);
    # dv is the ratio of site density for the electrode/electrolyte phases; ft2: normalized used in Equation 4.
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names  = 'kappa_op  M0     S1    S2     L    Ls       B   es       el    A     ul    us    AA  dv   ft2'
    prop_values = '0.3   317.9   1000000 1.19   6.25   0.001  2.4  -13.8  2.631   1.0   0.0695 13.8   38.69 5.5 0.0074'
  [../]
  [./liquid_GrandPotential]
    # grand potential of electrolyte phase
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = 'ul-A*log(1+exp((w-el)/A))'
    args = 'w'
    f_name = f1
    material_property_names = 'A ul el'
  [../]
  [./solid_GrandPotential]
    # grand potential of electrode phase
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = 'us-A*log(1+exp((w-es)/A))'
    args = 'w'
    f_name = f2
    material_property_names = 'A us es'
  [../]
  [./switching_function]
    #interpolation function h
    type = SwitchingFunctionMaterial
    eta ='eta'
    h_order = HIGH
  [../]
  [./barrier_function]
    # Barrier function g
    type = BarrierFunctionMaterial
    eta = eta
  [../]
  [./total_GrandPotential]
    type = DerivativeTwoPhaseMaterial
    args = 'w'
    eta = eta
    fa_name = f1
    fb_name = f2
    derivative_order = 2
    W = 2.4
  [../]
  [./coupled_eta_function]
    # Coupling between eta and w
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = '-(cs*dv-cl)*dh'  # in this code cs=-cs h=eta dh=1
    args = ' w eta'
    f_name = ft
    material_property_names = 'dh:=D[h,eta] h dv cs:=D[f2,w] cl:=D[f1,w]'
    derivative_order = 1
  [../]
  [./susceptibility]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = '-d2F1*(1-h)-d2F2*h*dv'
    args = 'w'
    f_name = chi
    derivative_order = 1
    material_property_names = 'h dv d2F1:=D[f1,w,w] d2F2:=D[f2,w,w]'
  [../]
  [./Mobility coefficient]
    # Mobility defined by D*c/(R*T), whereR*T is normalized by the chemical potential
    # M0*(1-h) is the effective diffusion coefficient; cl*(1-h) is the ion concentration
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = '-M0*(1-h)*cl*(1-h)'  #c is -c
    f_name = D
    args = 'eta w'
    derivative_order = 1
    material_property_names = ' M0 cl:=D[f1,w] h'
  [../]
  [./Free]
    # Energy of the barrier
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = FF
    material_property_names = 'B'
    args='eta'
    function = 'B*eta*eta*(1-eta)*(1-eta)'
    derivative_order = 1
  [../]
  [./Migration coefficient]
    # Migration coefficient.
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = '-cl*(1-h)*AA*M0*(1-h)'
    args = 'eta w'
    f_name = DN
    derivative_order = 1
    material_property_names = 'M0 AA cl:=D[f1,w] h'
  [../]
  [./Bultervolmer]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = 'Ls*(exp(pot*AA/2.)+14.89*cl*(1-h)*exp(-pot*AA/2.))*dh'
    args = 'pot eta w'
    f_name = G
    derivative_order = 1
    material_property_names = 'Ls dh:=D[h,eta] h cl:=D[f1,w] AA'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]
  [./concentration]
    # output the ion concentration
    type = ParsedMaterial
    f_name = c
    args='eta w'
    material_property_names = 'h dFl:=D[f1,w]'
    function = '-dFl*(1-h)'
    outputs = exodus
  [../]
  [./Le1]
    # Effective conductivity
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = Le1
    args = 'eta'
    material_property_names = 'S1 S2 h'
    function = 'S1*h+S2*(1-h)'
    derivative_order = 1
  [../]
[]

[GlobalParams]
  enable_jit = false           # Disable JIT
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = 'bdf2'
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  l_max_its = 50
  l_tol = 1e-4
  nl_max_its = 20
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
  dt = 0.02
  end_time = 400
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_grmres_restart -sub_ksp_type
                         -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      121                  preonly
                         ilu          8'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
  [./other]        # creates input_other.e output every 30 timestep
     type = Exodus
     interval = 30
  [../]
[]

[./Migration coefficient]
    # Migration coefficient.
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = '-cl*(1-h)*AA*M0*(1-h)'
    args = 'eta w'
    f_name = DN
    derivative_order = 1
    material_property_names = 'M0 AA cl:=D[f1,w] h'
  [../]

must be
  [./Migration_coefficient]
    # Migration coefficient.
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    function = '-cl*(1-h)*AA*M0*(1-h)'
    args = 'eta w'
    f_name = DN
    derivative_order = 1
    material_property_names = 'M0 AA cl:=D[f1,w] h'
  [../]

Spaces are not allowed in object names.
OK. I'll try. Thank you.
Mobility coefficient, too
Thank you.

node.title: Out of range errors for water equation of state #porous_flow #fluid_properties
node.bodyText:
I have a simulation case where one boundary is practically at the lower pressure and temperature range for the water EOS (1 ATM and 15C) --  the issue--on transient simulation I get out of range errors as the solver iterates.  These stop all meaningful progress of my simulation.
Has anyone modified the water EOS so that when it goes out of range it DOES NOT return the error but just a warning, and gives the simulation the nearest set of fluid properties?  This requires changing the water EOS to be able to provide fluid properties for conditions that are seemingly below freezing......but this is only a result of the solution process, its not physical in the simulation.
I tried using tabulated fluid properties and manually extended the table to go to low temperatures and pressures--and then changed the range provided in the input file--to no avail......
tagging @andrsd @WilkAndy

Also @cpgr will probably be able to say something useful.
I was going to suggest tabulated fluid props.  I wonder why that didn't work.  Did you just not extrapolate enough, or is the physics actually driving you away from the end regions (eg, your simulation keeps trying to reduce temperature or pressure)?   If you use higher pressure or temperature, just as a trial, does MOOSE behave OK?  I wonder whether bounds in the Newton process would help here (usually they just result in crappy convergence)?

Hmmm, they are supposed to throw an exception so that the timestep gets cut, not throw an error and quit.
And strange about tabulated fluid props not working in this case either if you extend the boundaries, as I thought it would just return the end value.
Is it a pressure out of range type error message or something else?

Thanks @crgr and @WilkAndy  you are right, it does just cut the timestep—which eventually drive the simulation to fail.

It has been a while since I had this issue, I’ll run it again and get a better description, and also test moving the BC away from the EOS min values
…
--
Robert K. Podgorney, PhD
Chief Computational Scientist
Advanced Scientific Computing Division
Idaho National Laboratory

Office: 208-526-1524<tel:208-526-1524>
email: ***@***.******@***.***>

Subject: [EXTERNAL] Re: [idaholab/moose] Out of range errors for water equation of state #porous_flow #fluid_properties (Discussion #19135)

Hmmm, they are supposed to throw an exception so that the timestep gets cut, not throw an error and quit.

And strange about tabulated fluid props not working in this case either if you extend the boundaries, as I thought it would just return the end value.

Is it a pressure out of range type error message or something else?

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://gcc02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fidaholab%2Fmoose%2Fdiscussions%2F19135%23discussioncomment-1498795&data=04%7C01%7Crobert.podgorney%40inl.gov%7C66af2fdadfc4452328d708d9928056a1%7C4cf464b7869a42368da2a98566485554%7C0%7C0%7C637701902178744576%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=XUhtrIUrR%2FxYO%2B%2BdRBF3a4PLD2og5JTlFjz6oULd7EQ%3D&reserved=0>, or unsubscribe<https://gcc02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fnotifications%2Funsubscribe-auth%2FACWGDT34JCP4HBDJS7TE45LUHSIIPANCNFSM5GHCJRTA&data=04%7C01%7Crobert.podgorney%40inl.gov%7C66af2fdadfc4452328d708d9928056a1%7C4cf464b7869a42368da2a98566485554%7C0%7C0%7C637701902178754535%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=NCnm4iHZUmNJJI%2F8Sd7Ou5NnerE5LdBr7vmLJLie3eY%3D&reserved=0>.
Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS<https://gcc02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fapps.apple.com%2Fapp%2Fapple-store%2Fid1477376905%3Fct%3Dnotification-email%26mt%3D8%26pt%3D524675&data=04%7C01%7Crobert.podgorney%40inl.gov%7C66af2fdadfc4452328d708d9928056a1%7C4cf464b7869a42368da2a98566485554%7C0%7C0%7C637701902178754535%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=pQzJcNy1NrpKVX04YGpHJRdfCbv3Lhaa%2FeJJNJhnGPo%3D&reserved=0> or Android<https://gcc02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fplay.google.com%2Fstore%2Fapps%2Fdetails%3Fid%3Dcom.github.android%26referrer%3Dutm_campaign%253Dnotification-email%2526utm_medium%253Demail%2526utm_source%253Dgithub&data=04%7C01%7Crobert.podgorney%40inl.gov%7C66af2fdadfc4452328d708d9928056a1%7C4cf464b7869a42368da2a98566485554%7C0%7C0%7C637701902178754535%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=o6PfU8EveYLmqtdcaA%2FKYwzQWwej%2FnuXpTRyZYUM7x4%3D&reserved=0>.

IMO if you are outside of the range of validity you have 2 options: (1) extend the range of validity of the fluid property class, (2) change your model so you are within the range of validity.
Regarding NaNs: I would highly recommend that Water97FluidProperties class gains the functionality of NaNInterface. Look at this PR we did today what I mean by that. It is a trivial change that gives users option to threat NaNs as errors, warnings or ignore them.
If anybody decides to implement it, feel free to request a review from me. Obviously, other classes in the FP module would benefit from this as well, not only Water97FluidProperties :-)
Thanks for introducing NaNInterface. I'll get around to including it in the classes when I get a chance

Thanks for introducing NaNInterface. I'll get around to including it in the classes when I get a chance

Cam we use this within PorousFlow, @cprg?  Off the top of my head, i can't think of anywhere especially appropriate.  Eg, the relperm curves have bounds, but i think it's an error if somehow the saturation goes outside those.
Not sure. I think we return the bounds of ref perm if saturation goes outside range, rather than throw an exception.
Just for the record NaNInterface can be used with any object, not just FluidProperties - I realized :-) Maybe, it should go into framework, really...

Thanks everyone---I explored this in detail yesterday.  The simplest answer was that the problems I was have were due to user error.  I am not able to extend the tabulated range and run my problems just fine.

node.title: Advanced restart with distributed mesh
node.bodyText:
I saw on the MOOSE documentation that the advanced restart option was only supported for serial meshes, but I was wondering if it could be possible to use advanced restart on a simulation that used a distributed mesh (with the same number of processors).
I tried to do it, but I get the following error:
*** ERROR ***
ERROR: Neither one of the following files can be located:
        '<checkpoint_file_directory>/####_mesh.cpr/1/header.cpr' nor
        '<checkpoint_file_directory>/####_mesh.cpr'
If you are running a parallel job, double check that you've created a split for 1 ranks.

The reason is that because I am using a distributed mesh, the ####_mesh.cpr directory contains a folder named with the number of splits, which is not equal to 1. The file header.cpr therefore exists, but in 16, for example, not in 1.
Is there a way to solve this issue and still use the advanced restart option, or if I should use the Variable Initialization method instead?
And as a follow up question, how do I make sure that the new simulation also uses a distributed mesh?
Thank you! Let me know if you need additional information.

Hello
If it's not supported then we need to develop it. I'll try this soon just to check.
Can you please try the restart using distributed Exodus (nemesis output) in the meantime?
Guillaume

Seems solutionUOs are not supported for distributed restart #3201
But distributed advanced restart (with checkpoint = recover) should be supported, we even have a recipe for it #9649
I think you can see it in action here: https://civet.inl.gov/job/842975/
Any news on this?

Thanks for the insight @GiudGiud !
The error I mentioned above can be removed using:
parallel_type = DISTRIBUTED
skip_partitioning = true

in the mesh block. That should be enough to fix the error when SolutionUOs is not in use.
However, since I am using SolutionUOs to define a polycrystal I unfortunately cannot use the advance restart option, as you mentioned. When I try, I get an error with EXIT CODE: 11 before calculating the first non-linear residual.
So I will be using the Variable Initialization feature described here.
Hopefully that helps anyone with a similar issue in the future.

node.title: Unsupported Order: 257
node.bodyText:
Hello. I'm running SAM/MOOSE simulation for a reactor geometry I made using TRELIS and am confused on why I'm getting the following error. Couldn't understand the error-code or find any information online where to start debugging.
The error occurs after adding component physics. Here is a screen shot of some error code.
Anything helps!

I normally get this when the variables are of a higher order than the elements in your mesh, e.g. using a second order variable with quad4 elements. What elements and order of variables are you using?
Thank you so much! Just realized I was using second order when trying element HEX8. I changed all my second order equations to first order and was able to get the simulation running.

node.title: inverse modelling using MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
@cpgr and i have a model containing some MaterialProperties that we'd like to estimate.  We do this by comparing the MOOSE outputs with experimental measurements.  We'd like to iteratively converge to the solution using Levenberg-Marquardt or Newton (or similar).  So, the steps are:

Initialize model with guestimates for the Property values
Run MOOSE with the current Property values, and calculate the objective function (difference between MOOSE output and experiment)
Modify the Property values one-by-one and Run MOOSE each time, calculating the change in the objective function.
Calculate the Jacobian (change in objective function / change in Properties) and use Newton (or whatever) to update the Property values to reduce the objective function.  Goto 1, until the process converges.

We can do this process outside MOOSE, but it'd be great to use some MOOSE tools, if they exist.  Obviously (2) is embarrassingly parallel, and that's where the algorithm will spend its time.
Any suggestions?
a
@lynnmunday @zachmprince

Hi Andy,
we are working on this right now.  We have a new optimization executioner that is using TAO and the multiapp system to run the forward and adjoint problem.  We are in the process of getting this code cleaned up and made available in an external app called isopod.  I don't think it is clean enough to go into MOOSE.  I think it is going to be another few weeks before I have it documented and the tests passing and then we can make it available.

Hi Andy, we are working on this right now. We have a new optimization executioner that is using TAO and the multiapp system to run the forward and adjoint problem. We are in the process of getting this code cleaned up and made available in an external app called isopod. I don't think it is clean enough to go into MOOSE. I think it is going to be another few weeks before I have it documented and the tests passing and then we can make it available.

Do you think we can wait for "another few weeks", @cpgr ?   My thought is we can't.
@lynnmunday , if it's going to be publicly available, can you give us access now?
a

@WilkAndy @cpgr, I just added you to the (temporary) Isopod repository so you can check it out. There is a  material inversion example in test/tests/formfunction/objective_minimize/material/. This example uses a gradient-free solver, so it is pretty inefficient, but based on your suggested algorithm it doesn't sound like that is much of a problem.  A good initial guess is very important here.
Long-time expect such a tool. Wait for isopod!
Hope this module can go into MOOSE soon!

Thanks @zachmprince and @lynnmunday. As @WilkAndy said, we probably would have had to hack something together ourselves as we are time constrained with this problem, so letting us access your work is a great help and very generous.
I second that!  This is great - i'm just compiling isopod now.

We had a similar situation where we want to adjust a parameter so the eigenvalue from calculation is equal to 1. We ended up writing our own solve object (or just executioner) with Newton method. The parameter must be something controllable in the input and the executioner accepts the parameter name. It will be nice to generalize this to multi-dimensional problems with the number of equations equal or greater than the number of parameters.

i would definitely like to hook Griffin in with isopod at some point. It works by computing an adjoint for the derivative in the parameter space, which is well defined for neutron transport. But it is probably overkill for something like criticality search.

If this is a very simple 1D optimization problem, with a Real controllable parameter, you can also use the PIDTransientControl to use a PID controller to converge on the solution (as evaluated by postprocessors) during a pseudo transient

node.title: Control input parameter consistently in multi-level multiapps
node.bodyText:
I would like to gather output data from a problem with different input parameters. The problem is designed as a multi-app problem, where one master app calling the full solve of one sub-app (master_app ->sub_app). The master-app and sub-app solves for different physics, but shares some input parameters that I'd like to perturb.
So what I am trying to do is to have a control app, which samples the input parameters and controls the master-app by using MultiAppCommandLineControl. However, I am not sure how to change the input parameters in the sub-app accordingly (e.g., for one sample, I'd like to keep the input parameters consistent between the master-app and the sub-app).
@zachmprince would you mind providing some suggestions here?

This is how I would do this. So you have three files: stm.i (the stochastic tools driver), main.i (the main physics app), and sub.i (the sub physics app). Let's say you want to perturb the parameter value in a BodyForce kernel of a sub app.
sub.i:
[Kernels]
  [force]
    type = BodyForce
    variable = u
    value = 1 # Fake value
  []
[]

main.i
bf_value = 1 # Fake value, which is sent to the sub app

[MultiApps]
  [sub]
    ...
    cli_args = 'Kernels/force/value=${bf_value}'
  []
[]

stm.i:
[Controls]
  [cmdline]
    type = MultiAppCommandLineControl
    ...
    param_names = 'bf_value'
  []
[]

The stm app will control the parameter bf_value in the main app which will subsequently send it to the kernel parameter in the sub app.

Thanks @zachmprince ! It is really nice that we can put cli_args  in the MultiApps .
It seems to be the case though that we can only have one cli_args per sub-app. Any idea how to pass multiple parameters for one sub-app?
You can have multple values using cli_args='Kernels/force1/value=${bf_value1};Kernels/force2/value=${bf_value2}. Note the ; separating the parameters and there can't be any spaces.
Oh that's right - I was using spaces, which were recognized as one input per sub-app. Thanks Zach! This works great now!
Let's document this trick with ; somewhere btw

node.title: Extract the component ID of a vector

node.bodyText:
_i should be the component index here.
You can look at the computeQpResidual routine to convince yourself
Guillaume

Hi @GiudGiud,
In my case _i loops from 0..8. Where, the vector is a 2D-vector of QUAD4 element. Therefore, I would like to know which _i is x-component, and which _i is y-component.
Thanks in advance,

oh true this is not as I thought.
Ok so this BC is built so that the residual is (usually) the result vector product, multiplied by the value of a vector. So all the components of the variable are involved in computing the residual.
See https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/bcs/VectorPenaltyDirichletBC.C for an example in framework/
and https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/navier_stokes/src/bcs/INSADMomentumNoBCBC.C for an example in the context of fluid flow.
You should not have to modify computeResidual btw. Only the computeQpResidual routines should need to be provided.

node.title: Conda stuck solving environment
node.bodyText:
Hello,
Im having trouble installing moose-tools and moose-libmesh on a linux cluster for continuous integration. I have followed the steps on the installation guide and when i get to the step:
conda install moose-tools
conda install moose-libmesh

where It gets stuck on Solving environment: ...working...  for hours. I have tried googling this error but i have found no solution which works. I have also tried the previous solution found on the moose form. I have tried installing libmesh first but it has not worked, and using conda clean. The CI has a time limit of 6 hours before it kills the process. Anyone have ideas for how to fix this?
Thanks,
Zack

Try this instead:
conda update --all
conda install mamba
mamba install moose-tools moose-libmesh

I get an error when installing mamba:
Preparing transaction: done
Verifying transaction: done
Executing transaction: failed
ERROR conda.core.link:_execute(502): An error occurred while installing package 'conda-forge::colorama-0.4.4-pyh9f0ad1d_0'.
OSError(2, 'No such file or directory')
Attempting to roll back.

Ah weird. Can you try again later? There s flukes with conda.
If it doesnt work can you try again from a fresh environment?
My boss was able to get it to work. Thanks for the help, installing with mamba did the trick

node.title: Are you not able to use DG kernels and MOOSE FV objects?
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am doing some testing with the incompressible Navier-Stokes module with MOOSE FVs. I wanted to couple the velocity field from FVs with another set of kernels for mass transport using DG methods. However, if I activate any DG kernels I get the following.
*** ERROR ***
dofIndicesLower not supported by MooseVariableFVBase
I also get this even if no FV variable is coupled to any non-FV variable. Is it not possible to have DG kernels active with FV stuff in MOOSE?

Hello
There's very limited support for FE-FV coupling right now. We have this PR that will start to improve this: #18394
but I dont know that it includes DG kernels.
What are you trying to do with those DG kernels? It s pretty likely it can be done in FV already, and if not we may want to add it
Guillaume

That's really cool. I hope FV improves the stability, it's easier to converge as far as I've noticed
@csdechant does your PR enable DG Kernels?
@lindsayad @rwcarlsen since you're reviewing that PR
#18394 should be agnostic of the backing FEType
But @csdechant has been hard to pin down recently 😄

node.title: Modify input parameter 'NAME' during runtime [Control]
node.bodyText:
Hi guys,
I'm wondering if it's possible to modify input parameter 'NAME' during runtime?
Since my simulation has quite a number of steps (100-300 mining frames), at each step we need to upload material property (damage) and it becomes very messy and might affect the memory usage of the simulation
for example at each time step we need to have 4 objects
userobject block
  [./damage_read_1]
    type = ElementPropertyReadFile
    prop_file_name = 'damage_1.csv'     ******** control name here
    nprop = 1
    read_type = element
  [../]

material block

  [damage_1]
    type = GenericConstantArrayTC
    prop_name = damage_1
    read_prop_user_object = damage_read_1   ******** or here
    []

  [./permeability_all_1]
    type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConstTC
    read_prop_user_object = perm_read
    damage = damage_1
    aw = 20
    kmax = 1e-7
  [../]
  
Control block
  [right_control]
    type = ConditionalFunctionEnableControl
    enable_objects = 'Materials::permeability_all_1'
    conditional_function = ''if(t=2,1,0)''
    execute_on = 'initial timestep_begin'
  []

instead, is it possible to just change the highlighted parameter name, base on the list from .csv file using [Control]?
in this case, I can just change the material/damage/read_prop_user_object  then everything can stay the same.
Or even better at userobject/ElementPropertyReadFile/prop_file_name = 'damage_1.csv'
for example
t1 userobject/ElementPropertyReadFile/prop_file_name = 'damage_1.csv'
t2 userobject/ElementPropertyReadFile/prop_file_name = 'damage_2.csv'
t3 userobject/ElementPropertyReadFile/prop_file_name = 'damage_3.csv'

in this case, i'd only need 100-300 control objects rather than 4x(100-300) objects in the input file.
I checked https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Controls/index.html
but not sure which one is the right one for me

Kind regards,
Traiwit

Not really. You can control objects, Real and bool. For some objects it would be totally valid to change a string, but for many others the string parameter is used to fetch a reference at initialization and changing the string during the simulation would just not do anything.
I think your solution here is to code the reading of a CSV file with a column for the time coordinate.

another solution would be to actually control the string (so add a new Control)
and to add a timestepSetup routine to the UserObject (or whichever system you want the Control to intervene on) and in that routine, query the right object after the control has run
The timestepSetup routine comes from the SetupInterface, make sure the object you want to use inherits that interface
Hi @GiudGiud, thank you! i'm still not sure if I understand all that yet, I need some time to digest and I will get back to you soon.

@GiudGiud, also a quick question, apparently it seems like my own material isn't controllable
The following error occurred in the object "damage_control_1", of type "ConditionalFunctionEnableControl".
this is the error message:
The desired parameter 'Materials::damage1/enable' was not located for the 'damage_control_1' object, it either does not exist or has not been declared as controllable.
I thought it'd work out of the box, BCs and UserObjects are controllable though, not sure why materials isn't, where should I look into this?
Kind regards,
Traiwit

How old is your MOOSE?
we have fixed that (Materials being controllable) a few weeks ago

How old is your MOOSE? we have fixed that (Materials being controllable) a few weeks ago

Hi @GiudGiud I updated it, seems like that problem is gone, but doesn't seem like it works properly
so I tested it with MOOSE default material
Control block
  [perm_1]
      type = ConditionalFunctionEnableControl
      enable_objects = 'Materials::permeability_1'
      conditional_function = 'if(t>=0 & t<1,1,0)'
      execute_on =  'initial timestep_begin'
  []
  [perm_2]
    type = ConditionalFunctionEnableControl
    enable_objects = 'Materials::permeability_2'
    conditional_function = 'if(t>=1 & t<2,1,0)'
    execute_on =  'initial timestep_begin''
  []

Materials block
    [permeability_1]
    type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConst
    permeability = '1e-9 0 0 0 1e-9 0 0 0 1e-9'
   []
  [permeability_2]
  type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConst
  permeability = '5e-9 0 0 0 5e-9 0 0 0 5e-9'
 []

So after T>=1, permeability_1 should be deactivate, but seems like it's still active
So i got this error right at the start of the simulation
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".

The following material properties are declared on block 2 by multiple materials:
  Material Property             Material Objects
  PorousFlow_permeability_qp    PorousFlow_density_nodal_all PorousFlow_density_qp_all PorousFlow_relative_permeability_nodal_all PorousFlow_relative_permeability_qp_all PorousFlow_viscosity_nodal_all PorousFlow_viscosity_qp_all permeability_1 permeability_2 porosity_nodal 
  dPorousFlow_permeability_qp_dgradvarPorousFlow_density_nodal_all PorousFlow_density_qp_all PorousFlow_relative_permeability_nodal_all PorousFlow_relative_permeability_qp_all PorousFlow_viscosity_nodal_all PorousFlow_viscosity_qp_all permeability_1 permeability_2 porosity_nodal 
  dPorousFlow_permeability_qp_dvarPorousFlow_density_nodal_all PorousFlow_density_qp_all PorousFlow_relative_permeability_nodal_all PorousFlow_relative_permeability_qp_all PorousFlow_viscosity_nodal_all PorousFlow_viscosity_qp_all permeability_1 permeability_2 porosity_nodal 

Moreover, when I removed Control/perm2 and Materials/permeability_2 the simulation still works fine even when T>1, but perm1 should be gone when T>1. This makes me think the permeability_1 is still there even I deactivate it.
Could you please help me look into this?
Kind regards,
Traiwit

Hi @GiudGiud all good now, I just need
[Problem]
  material_dependency_check = false
[]

in my input file, not sure why, but it works, I will test with an actual case and get back to you
merge the two control blocks and have a disable_objects parameter, i think that will help

merge the two control blocks and have a disable_objects parameter, i think that will help

I was thinking of doing that using TimePeriod, but when I have 120+ objects, I'm not sure how to chain them
rn I'm doing the simplest case where I have 120 control objects and 120 material objects

Ah yes.
Well if it works with 120 controls I m glad but you could just write a single control that handles a vector of inputs and only activates one at a time at this point.

Ah yes. Well if it works with 120 controls I m glad but you could just write a single control that handles a vector of inputs and only activates one at a time at this point.

yeh that's a good idea (similar to my constraints, I reckon), at this point I'm still not sure how to implement it with time, I know you posted about it above, but still not sure where to look for
